repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: on `CompleteDone` cursor can jump to the end of line instead of the end of ompleted word.

Solution: trim the part of the line that was cut off and pasted again.

Can fix #30656

comment_data.body:
If this "works", I would guess it's only by accident. The parameter is a row, not a column.

The `#line` arg looks suspicious, is that intentional @MariaSolOs ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -540,7 +540,7 @@ local function on_complete_done()
     -- Remove the already inserted word.
     local start_char = cursor_col - #completed_item.word
     local line = api.nvim_buf_get_lines(bufnr, cursor_row, cursor_row + 1, true)[1]
-    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_row, #line, { '' })
+    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_col, #line, { '' })

comment_data.body:
I agree that changing the `row` parameter to `col` might just be making the tests pass but not be a correct change.

Regarding `#line`, what do you find suspicious about it @justinmk?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -540,7 +540,7 @@ local function on_complete_done()
     -- Remove the already inserted word.
     local start_char = cursor_col - #completed_item.word
     local line = api.nvim_buf_get_lines(bufnr, cursor_row, cursor_row + 1, true)[1]
-    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_row, #line, { '' })
+    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_col, #line, { '' })

comment_data.body: Ah, I see. Being focused on creating the correct test I left the wrong untested change. The original change I tested manually was placed inside installed lua files and lost with next `make install`. Without checking I see that `#line` (like described in the issue, not `cursor_row`) should be probably change to `cursor_col`.

comment_data.body: I see that returning empty string can avoid that but not aware possibly side effect (and all tests from `./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua` passed for me).

comment_data.body:
> Even after changing the argument there is an incorrect "suffix" that is pasted after the completed word.

You'd also have to adapt the `suffix` logic.
`apply_snippet` no longer needs to have a `suffix` parameter and `clear_word` doesn't need to have a return value

```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/completion.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/completion.lua
index 71ea2df10..fa9cf3e88 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/completion.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/completion.lua
@@ -111,16 +111,15 @@ local function parse_snippet(input)
   end)
   return ok and tostring(parsed) or input
 end
 
 --- @param item lsp.CompletionItem
---- @param suffix? string
-local function apply_snippet(item, suffix)
+local function apply_snippet(item)
   if item.textEdit then
-    vim.snippet.expand(item.textEdit.newText .. suffix)
+    vim.snippet.expand(item.textEdit.newText)
   elseif item.insertText then
-    vim.snippet.expand(item.insertText .. suffix)
+    vim.snippet.expand(item.insertText)
   end
 end
 
 --- Returns text that should be inserted when a selecting completion item. The
 --- precedence is as follows: textEdit.newText > insertText > label
@@ -537,19 +536,16 @@ local function on_complete_done()
       return nil
     end
 
     -- Remove the already inserted word.
     local start_char = cursor_col - #completed_item.word
-    local line = api.nvim_buf_get_lines(bufnr, cursor_row, cursor_row + 1, true)[1]
-    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_row, #line, { '' })
-    return line:sub(cursor_col + 1)
+    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_row, cursor_col, { '' })
   end
 
-  --- @param suffix? string
-  local function apply_snippet_and_command(suffix)
+  local function apply_snippet_and_command()
     if expand_snippet then
-      apply_snippet(completion_item, suffix)
+      apply_snippet(completion_item)
     end
 
     local command = completion_item.command
     if command then
       client:_exec_cmd(command, { bufnr = bufnr }, nil, function()
@@ -563,37 +559,37 @@ local function on_complete_done()
       end)
     end
   end
 
   if completion_item.additionalTextEdits and next(completion_item.additionalTextEdits) then
-    local suffix = clear_word()
+    clear_word()
     lsp.util.apply_text_edits(completion_item.additionalTextEdits, bufnr, offset_encoding)
-    apply_snippet_and_command(suffix)
+    apply_snippet_and_command()
   elseif resolve_provider and type(completion_item) == 'table' then
     local changedtick = vim.b[bufnr].changedtick
 
     --- @param result lsp.CompletionItem
     client.request(ms.completionItem_resolve, completion_item, function(err, result)
       if changedtick ~= vim.b[bufnr].changedtick then
         return
       end
 
-      local suffix = clear_word()
+      clear_word()
       if err then
         vim.notify_once(err.message, vim.log.levels.WARN)
       elseif result and result.additionalTextEdits then
         lsp.util.apply_text_edits(result.additionalTextEdits, bufnr, offset_encoding)
         if result.command then
           completion_item.command = result.command
         end
       end
 
-      apply_snippet_and_command(suffix)
+      apply_snippet_and_command()
     end, bufnr)
   else
-    local suffix = clear_word()
-    apply_snippet_and_command(suffix)
+    clear_word()
+    apply_snippet_and_command()
   end
 end
 
 --- @class vim.lsp.completion.BufferOpts
 --- @field autotrigger? boolean Whether to trigger completion automatically. Default: false
```

     -- Remove the already inserted word.

-    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_row, #line, { '' })
+    api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, cursor_row, start_char, cursor_col, #line, { '' })

comment_data.body:
> Regarding `#line`, what do you find suspicious about it @justinmk?

Like in #30656 - the part from the end of the word to the end of line is appended to the string that is then expanded as a snippet.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it('puts cursor at the end of completed word', function()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -726,3 +731,68 @@ describe('vim.lsp.completion: protocol', function()
     end)
   end)
 end)
+
+describe('vim.lsp.completion: integration', function()
+  before_each(function()
+    clear()
+    exec_lua(create_server_definition)
+  end)
+
+  after_each(clear)
+
+  it('should put cursor at the end of completed word', function()

comment_regular_data.body: Still a draft while here is no test for #30656.

Probably I need help with creating test. I'm not sure if I can check the cursor position in `test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua` I tried 
```lua
  it('should put cursor at the end of completed word', function()
    local completion_list = {
      isIncomplete = false,
      items = {
        {
          insertText = "bo",
          insertTextFormat = 2,
          kind = 10,
          label = "bo?",
          sortText = "0001",
        },
      },
    }
    local expected = {
      abbr = "bo?",
      dup = 1,
      empty = 1,
      hl_group = "",
      icase = 1,
      info = "",
      kind = "Property",
      menu = "",
      word = "bo",
    }
    local line = 'vim._with({bo|}, f)'
    local cursor_col_before = line:find('|') - 1
    local result = complete(line, completion_list)

    local cursor_col_after = exec_lua(function ()
      return vim.fn.col(".")
      -- local row, col = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
      -- return col
    end)
    eq(cursor_col_before, cursor_col_after)
  end)
```
in `vim.lsp.completion: protocol` set.

> Probably I need help with creating test. I'm not sure if I can check the cursor position in `test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua` I

A new test probably isn't needed, just assert the cursor position in an existing test (may need to add some extra text to the initial buffer, to cover this scenario).

What problem did you have with checking `nvim_win_get_cursor` or `vim.fn.col(".")` ?

> What problem did you have with checking `nvim_win_get_cursor` or `vim.fn.col(".")` ?


With `return vim.fn.col(".")` (as above) I get
```
FAILED   ./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua @ 542: vim.lsp.completion: protocol should put cursor at the end of completed word
./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua:575: Expected objects to be the same.
Passed in:
(number) 1
Expected:
(number) 13
```

> > What problem did you have with checking `nvim_win_get_cursor` or `vim.fn.col(".")` ?
> 
> With `return vim.fn.col(".")` (as above) I get
> 
> ```
> FAILED   ./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua @ 542: vim.lsp.completion: protocol should put cursor at the end of completed word
> ./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua:575: Expected objects to be the same.
> Passed in:
> (number) 1
> Expected:
> (number) 13
> ```

In the snippet tests I use [this utility function](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/988482d9422b40e86225935326127063d881b090/test/functional/lua/snippet_spec.lua#L115) to verify the cursor position. Maybe try something similar?

> > > What problem did you have with checking `nvim_win_get_cursor` or `vim.fn.col(".")` ?
> > 
> > 
> > With `return vim.fn.col(".")` (as above) I get
> > ```
> > FAILED   ./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua @ 542: vim.lsp.completion: protocol should put cursor at the end of completed word
> > ./test/functional/plugin/lsp/completion_spec.lua:575: Expected objects to be the same.
> > Passed in:
> > (number) 1
> > Expected:
> > (number) 13
> > ```
> 
> In the snippet tests I use [this utility function](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/988482d9422b40e86225935326127063d881b090/test/functional/lua/snippet_spec.lua#L115) to verify the cursor position. Maybe try something similar?

You can see I tried it but forgot to `unpack` the result. 
```lua
    local cursor_col_after = exec_lua(function ()
      -- return vim.fn.col(".")
      local row, col = unpack(vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0))
      return col
    end)
```
The effect is the same (0 as the first column).

```lua
    local line = 'vim._with({bo|}, f)'
    local cursor_col_before = line:find('|') - 1
    local result = complete(line, completion_list)
    local cursor_col_after = exec_lua(function ()
      -- return vim.fn.col(".")
      local row, col = unpack(vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0))
      return col
    end)
    eq(cursor_col_before, cursor_col_after)

```
Is it possible that `complete` executes something asynchronously and `cursor_col_after` can be checked too early?
We need to test the callback attached to `CompleteDone` that is not executed in `completion_spec.lua` and is a local function. I need a different approach than what I originally proposed.

Now the problem is that **in the test** the result word is appended to the existing part instead of replacing it. For example completion `vim._with({no|}, f)` results with `vim._with({nonoautocmd}, f)`.

> (how to do?) simulate `vim.v.event.reason == 'accept'`.

looks like you figured that out, right? (`feed('<c-y>')`).


> Now the problem is that **in the test** the result word is appended to the existing part instead of replacing it. For example completion `vim._with({no|}, f)` results with `vim._with({nonoautocmd}, f)`.

but it works interactively? are you certain `trigger_at_pos` is triggering at the right position?

> but it works interactively? are you certain `trigger_at_pos` is triggering at the right position?

I have no problem with interactive use unless someone points out some untested use case.

> looks like you figured that out, right? (`feed('<c-y>')`).

Yes, `on_complete_done` is executed also in the test case, but I found that `clear_word` isn't. I suspect we need to add a resolve provider to the server.
Now I see that `vim.snippet.expand('noautocmd')` is executed in the test case, but the cursor still isn't placed as expected.

if there is potential for a race while waiting for the server request/response, may be worth trying `t.retry()` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/056009f74146b349c66790fbcba3130e85a6c6da/test/testutil.lua#L96

The problem has place before `CompleteDone`. To reduce complexity I put `vim.api.nvim_clear_autocmds({group = ('vim/lsp/completion-%d'):format(vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf())})` before `vim.v.completed_item = ...` and see that the buffer is not updated. Probably it was not necessary to any previous test. For example, the case `executes commands` behaves the same - we can see it adding 
```lua
    local col_line = exec_lua(function()
      return { vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[2], vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 0, 1, true)[1]}
    end)
    eq({5, 'hello'}, col_line)
```
at the end (the result is `{1, 'h'}`). 

I suspect that overriding `vim.fn.complete()` is not enough for this test, but still not understand why. After commenting it (with dependants) I get the correct result, both with and without `CompleteDone` autocommand.

> Probably it was not necessary to any previous test

sounds good. is this unblocked then?

Before the change I tried to catch the new cursor position using `retry` but with no success. 

Finally I created a separate test set with as much shared local functions as possible with original `vim.fn.complete`.

After switching to use original `vim.fn.complete` setting `vim.v.completed_item` stopped working. Now this assignment works under `CompleteDone` autocommand created before `vim.lsp.completion.enable` creates its own analogue.

title: fix(lsp): fix cursor position after snippet expansion
